title: Letter: Mao is still the template for China's economy
text:
Jamil Anderlini (“Ma personifies the conflict in China's ideology”, Opinion, March 2) seems perplexed by “the sharp and growing contradiction at the heart of the Chinese state”.

Clarity may come if he follows the advice of the student revolutionaries, who in the 1960s and 70s, from Berlin to Baltimore, hollered: “study Mao!”

Back in 1937 Mao wrote in his essay On Contradiction that “in given conditions, opposites possess identity, and consequently can coexist in a single entity”. Today Chinese communists continue to follow this tenet of Marxist dialectics.

In 1949, Mao's victorious communists did not “just nationalise private enterprise”. Indeed, they did not declare a socialist state but a people's democracy.

They inherited a semicolonial country dominated by feudal-paternal relationships with barely 3m industrial workers in a population of 600m. This dictated Mao's economic policy.

In On People's Democratic Rule, Mao invited the “national bourgeoisie” — those he considered patriotic among the capitalists who were willing to work with the communists — to participate in building a country that would develop steadily from an agricultural one into an industrial one and from what he called “new democracy” into a socialist one. Now, perhaps because the minds of many in the west are clouded by the “let a hundred flowers bloom”, “the Great Leap Forward” and “the cultural revolution” phases of China's development, they cannot see that President Xi Jinping's policy is a modern version of the communists' plans of 1949, and so should be analysed as such.

And, I would not worry too much about Goldman Sachs and BlackRock. If there are giant profits to be made in China, they will find a way.

Bryn Rowlands
Malmesbury, Wiltshire, UK
